characters: THE LONGSHOREMEN, THE BUSINESS EXECUTIVE, THE GROUNDSKEEP
"INDIANS WIN FIFTH STRAIGHT, CRACK FIRST DIVISION"
THE LOBBY OF THE STANLEY HOTEL
A PIECE OF LEOPARD SKIN FABRIC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three men in Cleveland Indian baseball caps sit at the  counter. BOBBY JAMES, 22-year-old grad student, VIC BOLIT 30-year-old telephone worker, and JOHNNY WYNN, 45-year-ol house painter. THELMA GORDON, 65-year-old waitress, deliv their breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring training starts the twelfth.  How do you think the Indians will do  this year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't look too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other two shake their heads in contemplation of this  sorry fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 45-year-old BUSINESS EXECUTIVE is talking to a fellow c member over lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't look particularly good,  do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two LONGSHOREMEN are talking while they unload a freighte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell ya. They don't look very  fuckin' good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down on the field, two KOREAN GROUNDSKEEPERS speak Korean they resod the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in subtitles) They're shitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TILT UP from the field to a glass-enclosed area on the third deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Cleveland Indians' conference room. Three men ar seated around the table; CHARLIE DONOVAN. the manager, PH BUTLER, public relations head, JERRY SIMMONS, operations  director and LYLE MATTHEWS director of player personnel  Donovan taps his pencil impatiently, obviously waiting fo somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Thirty minutes late. Think she'll  show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got to. She's the damn owner  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't last week. She was having  a guava facial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Butler tries to figure out what a guava facial is, the conference room doors swing open and a muscular MALE SECR BODYGUARD enters, clearing the way for MRS. RACHEL PHELPS flashy, striking woman in her early forties. Despite the  designer clothes she favors, there is the hint of somethi less refined about her. She carries a Pekinese dog, CHA-C on her left hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen. Welcome to  another season of Indians' baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men applaud, but their hearts are barely in it. The  Secretary-Bodyguard pulls out a chair at the head of the  table and Rachel sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that it may not seem the same  without Donald here this year, but I  promise you by the end of the season  this team will have made history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several eyes roll up around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up a newspaper) Unfortunately there are some in the  press who feel that... (reading from the  page) "the ex-showgirl wife of Donald Phelps  has no business being the owner of a  major league baseball team."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel crumbles the paper and throws it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously, Donald didn't feel that  way or he wouldn't have left the  team to me. And I was more than  showgirl. I was a dancer. Now, I  know some of you have doubts about  my ability to run this franchise.  God help you if I ever find out about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This causes a few nervous glances in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring training begins in two weeks. (throwing a sheet of  paper on the table) Here's the list of people we'll be  inviting to camp this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan, Butler and Simmons pour over the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could sit here and tell you what a  great year we're gonna have, but the  facts are we lost the two best players  we had to free agency. We haven't  won a pennant in 30 years. We haven't  even finished in the first division  for 15. Obviously it's time to make  some changes. What do ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of half these guys.  And the ones I do know are way past  their prime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of these guys never had a prime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the sheet) This guy here is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross him off then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Let's not be hasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to shake things up, Charlie.  Clear the board and start over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not the best material  I've ever had to work with, but I'll  do my best to see we move up a notch  this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you will, Charlie. That's why  I'm movin' you up to General Manager.  Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel sticks out her hand. Donovan shakes it somewhat fe bewildered by this whole development.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that should do it for today.  Thank you, gentlemen. Let's get to  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, Rachel gets up and breezes out of the room wit her entourage, leaving Donovan and the others dumbfounded

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) One minute, 58 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan, carrying a boxful of belongings under each arm,  pushes open the door of his new office and walks inside. basic outfitting is masculine enough, but the room is ful of feminine little accents; flowers in vases, porcelain d accessories etc. Donovan is slightly overwhelmed. Suddenl there's a voice at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan, Mrs. Phelps would like  to see you.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan is ushered in by Rachel's Male Secretary. Donovan carries his player roster with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in, Charlie. Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you called me in. I'm still  unclear on a couple things

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I'm the G.M., who's gonna  be the Manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking of Lou Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou Brown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's managed the Toledo Mud Hens of  the International League for the  last 30 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is hardly an impressive credential to Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he'll fit right in with our  team concept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly is our team concept?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted to talk to you  about. I want to put together a team  that will help us relocate to Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? (referring to the  roster) Some of these guys are furniture  movers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious about this, Charlie.  It's no secret I've never liked  Cleveland much. The weather's lousy,  downtown is a pit, the stadium's  falling apart, and we can't draw  dick. Another couple of years of  this and I'm gonna have to start  feeding Cha-Cha dog food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel bends down to give her dog, Cha-Cha, a little love pat, while Donovan tries to contain his disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Phelps, you can't just up and  move a team on a whim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hardly a whim. Miami's offered  to build us a new stadium -- 62,000  capacity, 45 V.I.P. boxes, and no  rent for the first million at the  gate. Plus a 12 million dollar media  guarantee; 45 percent of the  concession gross, all of the parking  and they pick up the stadium  operations costs. No other franchise  in baseball can match that deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even so, the League'll never let us  leave Cleveland. We got a lease with  the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lease says we have the right to  move if our attendance falls below  800,000 for the year. (pushing across a  copy of the lease) Paragraph 40, line 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan looks at it, the paragraph highlighted in yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we play bad enough, we should be  able to come in under that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying? You want us to  lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we've been losing. What I want  us to do is finish dead last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan is stunned. He casts around helplessly for some  response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Phelps would never have  approved of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew it had to be done. He just  didn't have the courage to do it. (with veiled menace) Hopefully, you will come to see the  wisdom of it. (pause) If this team lives up to its  potential, we could have the worst  record in all baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Donovan's sunken face, we go to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a stretch of deserted Mexican highway. OVER we hear a  telephone RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a total mess. The back door is off its hinges and a few chickens have wandered in. As they peck around debris, we PAN the room, taking in beer cans, food wrappe and finally a trail of hastily discarded clothes, both ma and female. We reach the bed and find our hero, JAKE TAYLOR, 35, and  with a couple days growth of stubble, passed out on his f Sprawled across him asleep is a MEXICAN WOMAN in her late twenties. She's not great looking, but at least she's  overweight. Taylor's hand fumbles to the RINGING telephon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Charlie Donovan calling from his office in Cleveland We CUT BACK AND FORTH between the two as we will in subse phone scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jake? This is Charlie Donovan,  new G.M. of the Cleveland Indians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Yeh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to call and say the  organization remembers you fondly  from the years you played here and  we'd love to have you come to spring  training for a shot at this year's  club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you, Tolbert? This isn't  very funny, ya know. I'm hung over.  My knees are killin' me. If you were  gonna pull this shit, you could've  at least said you were from the  Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor struggles to get a look up at the girl on top of h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still to Donovan) By the way, you were with me last  night. Who's this girl on top of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan is baffled by this whole line of conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolbert? Tolbert? Screw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor hangs up, leaving Donovan staring into his phone.  Taylor looks up to see TOLBERT standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolbert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell were you talkin' to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Taylor's reaction, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP LOU BROWN, a portly man in his early fifties,  making his way to his glass-partitioned office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lines three and four are waiting for  you, Mr. Brown. One guy about the TR- 70's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the phone) Tire World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou? This is Charlie Donovan, the  new G.M. of the Cleveland Indians.  Listen, Lou, I hope you're sittin'  down 'cause I got an offer you  probably been dreamin' about your  whole life. We been watchin' your  progress down there at Toledo with a  lotta interest and well... (a dramatic pause) How would you like to manage the  Indians this year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment there's silence on the line, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) What do ya mean you don't know? This  is a chance to manage in the big  leagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme think it over, will ya, Charlie.  I got a guy on the other line about  some whitewalls. I'll talk to ya  later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown clicks off. Donovan puts his head down on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan's on the phone to another player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick, we heard about your pitching  out at Portland last year...

dialogues.speaker: RICKY VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Good-looking, muscular, 19-year-old. Sleeveless black T-s Talking on a wall phone in a nondescript room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, ah, not with them anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn has been working, sweating slightly. He takes off cap to mop his brow -- revealing a RADICAL HAIRCUT with  PIGTAIL. He sports a RING in his left ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd still like to take a look at ya  at our spring camp in Arizona, March  first.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: In the b.g., Vaughn is on the phone. In the f.g., we see  security bars. Vaughn's in a Youth Authority prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, well, I'm not sure I can make  it by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we're gettin' you out  on a sort of work furlough deal. Any  questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. Where's Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the speaker again to Lou Brown. Rachel watches, impati for him to close the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Lou, you been in baseball thirty  years. Don't you wanna advance some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating a sack lunch) I used to coach the unwed mothers'  softball team. I have advanced some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel rubs her fingers together, making the money sign t Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what are you really worried  about? The money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I'm just not sure I'd be happy  in a big organization like that.  Owners are always on your back, tryin'  to "help you out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's gonna be a  problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down here baseball's a game, not a  business. I don't wanta be a  babysitter for a buncha millionaires  who think they know it all already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have any millionaires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, bonus babies or whatever  you got...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have any bonus babies either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have any proven major league  talent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Not that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then... I'll be up in a couple  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like my kinda team. Have my  contracts ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) Guess I really put the screws to  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's a dandy. The left field wall is a 20-foot high solid granite outcropping. A final out is made and the te change over.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: returning to the dugout at the end of the inning, wonderi what the hell he's doin' here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, telephone for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor goes to the phone in the clubhouse tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, Charlie Donovan again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeh, Charlie, look, I'm sorry  about this morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. Look, Jake, camp starts  on the first. Can you make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been stayin' in shape down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hell, yeh, I work out every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so. See ya in Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan hangs up. Taylor shoots a fist in the air, and we

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: approaching his MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Taylor. You're up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luis, I'm not gonna be playin'  anymore. I got a tryout in the States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Leave your uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I changed at the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave your uniform.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: coming out of the stadium, his bats and gloves over his  shoulder. He has on his spikes and a pair of boxer shorts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor sits in the back seat. He has six Coke bottles fil with sand strapped to his ankles. He lifts his legs up an down to strengthen his muscles.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan, Brown and two of his coaches, PEPPER LEACH (pitc and DUKE TEMPLE (hitting) are on the field, witnessing th arrival of their "troops." First to arrive is:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: He gets out of a taxi and goes to the trunk to get his ba and luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This looks like Jake Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown turns around from a conversation with Temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was an Allstar in Boston, wasn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish we had him two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years ago then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an Army barracks. Rows of bunk beds seperated by loc Taylor walks in with Temple, the hitting instructor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the private rooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on an austerity program. This  is what happens when you finish 24  games out.

dialogues.speaker: BROWN, PEPPER, TEMPLE AND DONOVAN
dialogues.text: back at the field, supervising the arrival of more player The first is a tall, muscular Latin, PEDRO CERRANO, dress in black from head to toe. He arrives on foot, carrying a black suitcase and pulling a black bat case on wheels. He looks like a gunfighter coming into Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's Cerrano. Defected from  Cuba. Wanted religious freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his religion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voodoo.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND TAN ROLLS-ROYCE
dialogues.text: pulling into the parking lot. Out steps RODGER DORN, high priced third baseman. Brown eyes him with vague disapprov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you didn't have any high- priced talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepish) I forgot about Dorn, 'cause he's  only high-priced. Got him as a free  agent three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still hits the ball pretty well,  doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, he just can't field it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorn pulls his golf clubs out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll shape him up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE HAYES
dialogues.text: a 22-year-old black, pulling up in a '72 VW Beetle which  he's got a Cadillac grille on. He steps out in his shades and sharkskin suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't recognize this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes strolls up and introduces himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hey, Willie Mays Hayes here. I  play like Mays and run like Hayes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou Brown. Nice to meet ya, Hayes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Well, I gotta get my stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes hustles off toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember a Hayes on the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcycle pulls to a stop in the lot, diverting everyo attention from Hayes. Off steps Ricky Vaughn, a hefty bag over his shoulder. He still sporting his radical do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this fuckin' guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's the mascot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan is speechless. Brown breaks into a small smile. Y sir, this is his kinda team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor is putting his stuff away in a locker. Vaughn ente the barracks and immediately draws the attention of Dorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what do we have here? Guy looks  like a fuckin' toilet brush. Hey,  T.B., I love your pony tail. And the  earring's cute too. Where's the  matching bracelet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn whips a hard glance at Dorn, but keeps on walking, making his way along the bunks looking for his assigned b It's the one above Taylor. Vaughn unloads his duffel bag silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering his hand) Jake Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn shakes it and nods. Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you just gonna settle for toilet  brush, or you got another name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn. Rick Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about Dorn. He's always a  little tough on rookies. You'll get  a lot worse from other teams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation is interrupted by the arrival of Hayes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hey! How ya doin'? Willie Mays  Hayes here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake Taylor. (pointing to Vaughn) Rick Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes doesn't quite know what to make of Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell league you been playin'  in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California Penal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of it. How'd you wind up  playin' there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Hayes' look, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark. Everyone's asleep. Three SECURITY GUARDS with  flashlights come down to the top bunk where Hayes is slee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy wasn't invited to camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lift the bunk out of its slots and carry it out the  door, Hayes still asleep on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are dressing out in their uniforms for the fi day of practice. Vaughn goes in his locker and finds that slit has been cut in the back of his cap to accommodate h pigtail. Suppressed laughs are heard from several corners the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown is addressing his troops before the first workout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Spring Training, gentlemen.  Most managers tell you at this time  that all the jobs are open, that  nobody's a lock at any position, and  that talent isn't everything. They'd  rather see desire and discipline in  a player. Then they tell you that  most of all they want you to have  fun out there, even though they're  gonna work your ass off on  fundamentals and condition you till  you drop. The difference between me  and those other managers is... (pause) I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a locker room full of uneasy faces, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes' cot is sitting in the lot, just outside the fence, his suitcase set down next to it. Hayes is still asleep, on his forehead. Wakened by the noise of activity on the  field, he sits up with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I been cut already?

dialogues.speaker: THE PRACTICE FIELD
dialogues.text: We pick up Taylor sprinting his ass off in a 100-yard tim trial, staggering across the finish line 10 feet behind  Cerrano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking stopwatch) 11.9 Taylor. Not bad if you'd fallen  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Taylor tries to catch his breath, Dorn and a relief pi named Gant approach the starting line for the next trial.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: looking through the chain-link fence surrounding the fiel

dialogues.speaker: DORN AND GENTRY AGAIN
dialogues.text: Temple brings them to their marks and blows his whistle.  Dorn and Gentry take off. Suddenly Hayes, in his pajamas and bare feet comes streak toward the starting line in hot pursuit. Dorn and Gentry good 10-yard lead, but Hayes is coming like a bullet. We to SLOW MOTION as Hayes draws even at the 80-yard mark an blasts on by to win by five. This kid is fast. Brown and  Pepper give each other the "Who was that Masked Man" look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The players are spread out on the field doing calisthenic counting off in unison.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: struggling through a series of pushups. He glances over i disbelief at Vaughn and Cerrano, who are doing them like  pistons in competition with each other. Cerrano even star doing them one-handed. Hayes isn't doing them at all; merely pulling his head up and down while leaving his body on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Hayes, let's do 'em right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, my philosophy is no pain, no  pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor is crouched behind the plate, warming up his arm.  Catching pitches and throwing them half-speed down to sec Brown drifts over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the knees holdin' up, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Never been better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mobility's good? No problem gettin'  off the throw to second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a catcher, Jake. Somebody who  can keep this team together on the  field. You were a helluva player  when you were sound, but around the  league they think you can't take the  pounding anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the league they're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna have to put you to the  test, ya know. So, I want the absolute  truth here. Are you 100 percent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. Would I bullshit about somethin'  like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away) You better if you wanna make this  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor smiles and fires one full-speed down to second. It bounces two feet in front of the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown is watching batting practice. Hayes steps into the cage and begins a preparatory ritual worthy of Babe Ruth -- rubbing dirt on his hands, stretch knocking dirt off his spikes, twirling the bat, etc. A re slugger's routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Hayes, this isn't the All  Star Game. Get up to the damn plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes gets in and takes his stance. On the first pitch, h takes a mighty cut and hits a pop-fly to the pitcher's mo We take QUICK CUTS of the next three pitches. Hayes takes prodigious swings at all of them, producing three more po ups, none out of the infield. Brown calls a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you may run like Mays, but you  hit like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My stroke'll come back once I get  warmed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to some  stats) Never did get warmed up last year.  Hit .211 at Maine. I looked him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Mr. Hayes shows some promise.  His speed could be a big asset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside) For what? Running back to the dugout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta stop swingin' for the fences  though, Hayes. All you're gonna do  is give yourself a hernia. With your  speed you should be hittin' the ball  on the ground, leggin' 'em out. Every  time I see you hit one in the air,  you owe me twenty pushups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next pitch comes in. Hayes swings and pops it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gets down to do his twenty, Brown turns to Temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you can teach a guy to  hit. You can't teach him to run.

dialogues.speaker: BROWN AND PEPPER
dialogues.text: coming over to where Vaughn is tossing some casual warm-u pitches to Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Vaughn, they tell us you're  a pitcher. Let's see what you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown and Pepper stand behind Taylor for a better view. V goes into his wind-up and fires a screaming fast ball tha Taylor has no chance to get out of his crouch to catch. T ball rockets an inch over Brown's head, and slams into th backstop. Brown stands frozen a second, contemplating his brush wit eternity, then turns to Pepper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice velocity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounded like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Lou, I wasn't quite expectin'  that much octane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown turns to the Clubhouse Man who's holding a speed gu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pepper) Better teach him some control before  he kills somebody.

dialogues.speaker: RODGER DORN
dialogues.text: fielding grounders at third base. He plays them off to hi left side a bit, almost as if he's afraid to get bit by t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Dorn, get in front of the  damn ball. (making like a  bullfighter) Don't give me this ole' bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took one of these in the eye last  year. Nearly lost my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm deeply moved. Every time you  play it off your hip, you give me  forty sit-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! That's Little League shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown strikes an effeminate fielding position, like Betty Grable shying from a mouse. Dorn burns.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO CERRANO
dialogues.text: in the batting cage, knocking the cover off pitch after p with his black bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, this guy hits a ton. How come  nobody else picked up on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the batting  practice pitcher) Okay, Harris, that's enough fast  balls. Throw some curves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harris winds and throws a fair-to-middlin' curve ball. Ce swings and misses it a foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorn approaches Brown at the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou, I wanna have a word with you  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whipping out his  contract) Those penalty sit-ups you want me to  do? I got it right here in my contract  that I don't have to do any  calisthenics I don't feel are  necessary. What do ya think of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone around the batting cage has stopped what they're doing to see how Brown will react. Brown looks at the con a second, then drops it on the ground, unzips his fly, an gives it a golden shower. On Dorn's stunned face, we...

dialogues.speaker: DORN
dialogues.text: doing sit-ups in the infield. Vaughn walks by and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LONGSHOT
dialogues.text: Practically every member of the team is doing penalty  calisthenics somewhere on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Temple) We got anybody left playin' baseball  out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn drag in, looking beat from the d workout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, the way I played today, I  wouldn't be surprised if they red- tagged me already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red tag in your locker means the  manager wants to see you, 'cause you  just died and went to the minors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn's hand freezes on his locker latch, afraid to open now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, they don't cut anybody  the first day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn is still not so sure. He sits down on his locker s and glances over toward STEVE HARRIS a starting pitcher,  whose locker is adjacent. As Harris takes off his jersey see three SPLOTCHES OF GREASY SUBSTANCES on his chest, ju inside the button line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to them in  order) Crisco, Bardahl, Vagisil. Any one of  'em will give you another 2-3 inches  drop on your curve ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn can't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course if it's cold and I got a shirt  on under my jersey, I just rub a  little jalapeno inside my nose and  get it runnin'. I need to load up  the ball a little, I just wipe my  nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (revolted) You put snot on the ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At my age, you put anything you can  find on it. I haven't got an arm  like yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn just looks at him incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR AND CARRANO
dialogues.text: Taylor is undressing, but his attention is diverted by Ce whose stall is right next to him. Cerrano has set up an a in his locker. In front of his bats, which are lined up l sentinels, is a table covered with pictures of baseball  players, figurines of saints, several lit candles and, in the middle, a primitive fetish doll with a cigar in its m Cerrano has drawn some magic signs on his bats. He finish an incantation and then lights the cigar on the fetish do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' there, Pedro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bats. They are sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are mine. Is somethin' goin'  around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hit curve ball. Straight ball,  hit it very much. Curve ball, bats  are afraid. I ask Jo-Buu to come.  Take fear from bats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo-Buu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's the pagan saint of  baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I offer him cigars and gin. He will  come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cerrano pours some gin in a small cup and puts it next to the fetish doll. Harris has been listening to all this.  Cerrano grabs a towel to head for the showers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't leave this gin sittin'  around out here with this group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a certain gravity) Is very bad to steal Jo-Buu's gin.  Is very bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cerrano closes his locker and goes off to the showers, le everyone to wonder just how bad.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: compressing and detailing the progress of spring training We see: A) Vaughn on the pitcher's mound. A tin replica of a batt has been set up at home plate and rope stretched across t plate to delineate the strike zone. Vaughn fires a pitch hits the tin batter in the hip, leaving a dent in him. B) Cerrano in the batting cage, flailing away in futility several curve balls.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: doing push-ups at night. He's the only one left on the fi except Temple, who supervises.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: doing the "scramble" drill -- blocking down balls purpose thrown in the dirt, one after another. When it ends, he c hardly get to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: waving a ten-foot BOA CONSTRICTOR in the sign of the cros in front of his locker before opening it. No red tag gree him. Hayes watches from a safe distance.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: holding a mirror under the vents on his locker door to ge peek inside to see if there's a red tag there.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: taking a hard ground ball off the chest. Brown applauds.  Dorn is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: throwing at the "ropes" again. The tin batter is dented i every conceivable place now. Vaughn whips in another fast ball. This one hits the tin man in the head, knocking it  completely off.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: in an exhibition game, attempting to throw out a base ste Jake springs out of his crouch and fires down to second - on a bounce. The ball skips into center field.

dialogues.speaker: J
dialogues.text: also in an exhibition game, swinging at a pitch and poppi it up behind the plate. He just drops in his tracks and s to do push-ups as the catcher makes the catch behind him.

dialogues.speaker: K
dialogues.text: flailing away again at a curve ball. This and the remaini shots are all in exhibition games.

dialogues.speaker: L
dialogues.text: waving a ten-inch garter snake in front of his locker. Ev at this size we can tell it scares the hell out of him, b it works its magic. No red tag.

dialogues.speaker: M
dialogues.text: with a runner on third, winding up and throwing a pitch f feet over Taylor's head. The run scores.

dialogues.speaker: N
dialogues.text: attempting to steal second. He goes into a hell-bent-for- leather head first slide. Unfortunately, he comes up two  feet short of the base. The second baseman, who's waiting for him with the ball, makes a motion for him to keep com Hayes flips him the bird.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: on the bench. He turns to Pepper with a look that says, " you believe this shit?"

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: waiting for a throw at the plate. Just as he's about to c it, the runner knocks him flat.

dialogues.speaker: Q
dialogues.text: his head in his hands. As Taylor gets up and goes to the  wrong dugout, the MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players are filing off the team bus after the game. We PI UP Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn as they head toward the locke room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is final cut down day, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, better get your snake ready,  Hayes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm goin' cold turkey today. My  hands are too screwed up to hold it  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes reveals a pair of red and cut hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're gonna use that head first  slide, you better get yourself some  gloves or you're not gonna have any  skin left on your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've reached the locker room now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna go in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever happens, keep it to yourself  until you're outta the locker room.  Don't celebrate in front of guys who  just died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we're one of the deceased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor goes into the locker room. Hayes and Vaughn hang b Cerrano is already at his locker. He's got two snakes thi time and some kind of voodoo head dress on. He sprays a p of white paint on the locker door from a spray can, draws symbol door. No tag. He kisses the snake, leaving some wh paint on his lips, like a kid who's just had a glass of m Taylor, exhausted from the game, lifts his latch and peer inside. He's made it, too. Cerrano offers a hand. Taylor  shakes it and breaks a weary smile.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: opens locker, slumps on stool. He's a goner.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES AND VAUGHN
dialogues.text: the two rookies, are still hanging back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Vaughn, let's show some nuts  here. If they cut us, we'll just  sign with the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes strides manfully to his locker and pulls it open. T doesn't tell him much, however, because he's got his eyes closed. He stands that way a beat ot two, then opens one  eye. Seeing no tag, he turns and walks double-time out of the  locker room, as if he had to get to the john. He comes outside, turns a corner, and starts leaping arou like a wild man.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: drawing strength from Hayes, walks resolutely to his lock and whips it open. There hanging from the top hook is the "red death." Vaughn stares at it expressionless, then slo closes his locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn goes right in without knocking and leans on Brown' desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got news for you, Mr. Brown. You  haven't heard the last of me. You  think I'm shit now, but someday you'll  be sorry you cut me. I'm gonna catch  on somewhere else, and every time I  pitch against you, I'm gonna stick  it up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, I like that kinda spirit in a  player. The only problem is, I didn't  cut you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think somebody's been havin' fun  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We GO TO Vaughn, his faced a mask of anger and embarrassm

dialogues.speaker: THE LOCKER ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Vaughn charges across the room and jumps Dorn. The men gr and fight all over the room, until Taylor finally gets th separated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vaughn) What's the matter, little lady? Can't  you take a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn gives Dorn a look that indicates this isn't over. Brown enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have your attention, please? I  counted up your ballots for team  captain and I think you chose the  right guy. If you hadn't, I woulda  told you he won anyway. Mr. C for  the year -- Jake Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team breaks into applause and whistles as Taylor's na is announced. Dorn is the only one who seems unhappy abou it. As Taylor accepts the congratulations of his teammate he turns to Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about Dorn. You got other  things to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packing for Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor gives him a wide smile. Vaughn finally allows hims one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as it is. We MOVE DOWN to the same diner we saw duri the opening of the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same three guys as before are at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the new lineup the Indians  got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of most of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Business Executive is talking to the limo driver as h reads the sports section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the majority of these  names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Longshoremen again, looking at a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these fuckin' guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Korean Groundskeepers again, dragging the infield

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in subtitles) They're shitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor is alone in the stadium, standing near home plate his street clothes, taking in the massive stadium, rememb glories past. He steps into the batter's box and takes hi stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Two down. Bottom of the ninth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor points to the left field stands. He imagines a pit coming in, takes a mighty swing and admires the flight of the imaginary ball as it arches high in the mid-day sky,  landing deep in the left field seats. Breaking into his h run trot, he circles the bases, slapping the third base  coach's hand and exchanging low fives with his teamates a he reaches the plate. Suddenly, his reverie is interrupted by the sound of appl He turns and looks in the dugout, where Hayes and Vaughn giving him a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really got all of that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it? A slider?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor is too embarrassed to reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Cleveland's finest. Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn are s at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. What language is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got patty melts over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I'll order. Let's have a  toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three raise their wine glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to baseball, here's to the  start of two great careers, and for  me, here's to at least one more good  year in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glasses CLINK. Suddenly Taylor's attention fixes on  something across the room -- a stunning young woman in he late twenties, LYNN WESTLAND. She's having dinner with a  DATE in a three-piece suit. Hayes and Vaughn follow Taylor's eyes to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? The chick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean she woulda been if I hadn't  screwed it up. Who's that guy she's  with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He's not wearing a  name tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to beat the shit out of  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a librarian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A librarian? Shit, I gotta start  readin' again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITER approaches the table where Lynn and her date are sharing a dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wells, there's a telephone call  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn is somewhat surprised, but gets up to take the call. FOLLOW her to the pay phone in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Lynn. It's Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake? How did you know I was here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a hunch. I took you there when  you got your masters. I figure you're  probably wearing the black velvet  dress with the red sash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is indeed. Lynn is a little unsettled by this display clairvoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know that? I didn't have  this dress when we were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensing that something's askew, she turns and looks acros the way to see Jake talking to her on the pay phone on th other side of the hall, maybe ten feet away. He gives her his best grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn, as is often the case with Jake, is both charmed and put-out. She goes with put-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. What are you doin' here?  Aren't you supposed to be in Mexico  somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm playin' with the Indians again.  Back in the Bigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. I'm happy for you,  Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she is. Not so sure about herself, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting away) I gotta get back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What's your number. I  tried calling you at home, but you're  not listed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life is different from when you  knew me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning what? That I don't know you  anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't we talk about this some  other time? I really gotta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just gimme your number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Because of the guy you're  with? What is he, a banker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawyer. Please, Jake, he's watching  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leavin' without your number.  You still wear those great little  tortoise-shell glasses? I always  loved it when you took them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Jake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number, Lynn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant) All right. 555-9314.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm back, Lynn, and I'm  gonna be around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him a beat, unsure what to say, then heads b toward her table. We go to Lynn's date. None of this has  been lost on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn are the fares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the number again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at a piece  of paper) 1036.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furnished apartment building owned  by the Indians. We get special rates.  With what we're makin' we'll need  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cabbie pulls to a stop and points to the other side o the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor and the others turn to see a dismal, run-down buil with a neon sign that says "The Turk."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Big Leagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake goes to a pay phone in the hall and dials the number Lynn gave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Cuyahoga Sheet Metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor doesn't like the sound of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got anybody workin' there named  Lynn Wells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor hangs up, staring off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various players are dressing out for the game. We PICK UP Cerrano putting on his undergarments. They're all black,  including his jock. Dorn reads the Wall Street Journal, w Taylor sits on the trainer's table getting his knees tape Hayes checks the fit of his new uniform from every angle a mirror. He thinks he looks pretty good. Vaughn just squ a baseball in his left hand, obviously a little uptight.  Taylor gives him a chuck on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. We got 162 of these to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou Brown enters the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's gather 'round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players turn their attention to Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not much for inspirational  addresses. I just wanta point out  that every newspaper in the country  has picked us to finish last. The  local press thinks we'd save everybody  a lot of time and trouble if we just  went out and shot ourselves. Me, I  like to waste sportswriters' time so  I'm for hangin' around and seein' if  we can give all these guys a nice  big shitburger to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we gonna have a prayer? I  mean we're not all savages like  Cerrano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys go ahead. I belong to the  church of three-run homers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's bow our heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many of the players follow suit. Suddenly the silence is  shattered by a loud explosive SOUND, scaring the hell out everybody. All eyes turn to Cerrano, who has just set off charge of gunpowder on his locker altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to wake up bats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, Harris and the others turn back to their praye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, we ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harris never gets to finish. The smoke rising from Cerran gunpowder explosion sets off the automatic sprinklers in ceiling. As Harris and the faithful look up into the down we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stands are nearly empty. Of the fans who have showed many wear doormats around their necks. Bobby, Vic, Johnny and Thelma, our four fans from the din sit alone in the vast expanse of the centerfield bleacher All four wear Indian head dresses and have war paint on t faces. The three men each have tom-toms. Thelma works on needlepoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read the Plain Dealer today?  They said this is gonna be the worst  Indian team we've had in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody laughs at the Indians now,  but there were other times. Even won  the Series in '48. Then Willie Mays  made that catch on Vic Wertz in the  '54 Series and Cleveland's never  been the same since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Indians go so goes Cleveland,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we ever lost the Indians, Cleveland  would die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get our fist glimpse of HARRY DOYLE, the Indians' 55-y old radio announcer. Harry's never walked past a bar in a He's been with the Indians through thin and thinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) Hello, everybody, Harry Doyle here,  welcoming all you Friends of the  Feather to another season of Indians  baseball. (pouring some Jack  Daniels in his Coke) A lotta new faces for the tribe this  year, as they take on the defending  American League champs, the New York  Yankees. And listen to the roar of  the crowd as the Indians takes the  field!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle leans out the press box window with his mike, tryin to pick up the sound of a couple guys CLAPPING down below

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, they love this club here  in Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle takes a hit of his spiked Coke.

dialogues.speaker: A YANKEE HITTER
dialogues.text: flies out to Hayes, who makes a "basket" catch a la Willi Mays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High fly ball, centerfield. Hayes  under it now... Oh, makes a basket  catch, Willie Mays style, and the  side is retired.

dialogues.speaker: THE INDIAN DUGOUT
dialogues.text: The team comes in off the field to much enthusiasm and ba slapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, way to look, way to look.  Nice catch, Hayes. Don't ever fuckin'  do it again. Okay, let's get it goin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottom of the first, Willie Mays  Hayes to lead it off for the tribe.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: going through his warmup routine at the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lotta people say you can tell how  a season's gonna go by the first  hitter of the year. In the last  fifteen years, the Indians have never  had the season lead-off hitter reach  base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes is in the batter's box now. The Yankee pitcher wind and fires. Hayes swings and hits a little dribbler toward the second baseman, who races in and scoops it up bare-ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot shot toward the hole. Rudia knocks  it down, gets up, fires to first.  Too late! Hayes beats it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle leans out the window again trying to pick up some  cheering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so the string is broken. Maybe  things will turn around a little for  the Indians this year.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: Our four fans (from here on known as the Bleacher Band),  overjoyed by Hayes' hit, start beating the tom-toms and  singing a fight song they've composed called "In the Land Burning Waters" to the tune of the old Hamms Beer jingle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the land of burning waters, waters  Lurks the Injun nine, oh so fine, we  Love those mighty Redmen, Turn their  foes to dead men, Ummmmm.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BASE AREA
dialogues.text: as Hayes comes back to the bag, where the Yankee FIRST BA is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showed some real power on that one,  Slugger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan to get at least a double out  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes reaches in his back pocket and pulls out one of the pairs of black leather gloves he bought earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now Hayes is putting on a pair  of black gloves, sending a little  message to the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the First Baseman) Bought a hundred of these, one for  each base I plan to steal. Excuse  me, here, I gotta take my first step  toward the Hall of Fame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes takes his lead-off and crouches, ready to steal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look real sharp, but you'll never  steal second with your shoe untied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes looks down at his shoe. It's not untied. He notices too late that the PITCHER is throwing over to pick him of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brewster, quick move to first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes dives back for the bag, but never gets there; his f smashing up against the First Baseman's glove, which is  already holding the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got him. Hayes is picked off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice base running, dildo. Hard to  get your thumb out of your ass with  the gloves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes lies in the dust humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so much for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle takes a long pull on his Coke and we GO INTO A MONT depicting the Indians' progressive disintegration in this game. We see: A) THREE FIELDERS converging on a short pop fly into left field. They all collide and go down in a heap as the ball drops untouched. B) DORN playing a grounder off his hip. He fumbles it, pi it up, fumbles it again. No play. C) TAYLOR crouched behind the plate, but up off his haunc ready to throw. We hear the voice of his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's goin'. Gotta be goin'... get  the throw up. Don't bounce the damn  ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The runner on first takes off as the pitch comes in. Tayl catches the ball and fires down to second. The ball sails three feet over the second baseman's head and on into cen field. Taylor stands there, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice throw, dickhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D) CERRANO striking out on a curve ball. He bawls his bat out on the way to the dugout. E) THE THREE FIELDERS we saw before, converging on anothe pop fly into short left. This time all three dive off at last instant to avoid a collision. Once again the ball dr untouched. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: It shows Yankees 4, Indians 0 after five innings.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE UP IN THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: There are two empty Coca-Cola cups near the mike. He's wo on a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top of the sixth. Rookie sensation,  Ricky Vaughn, on to pitch now. You  can close the book on Winters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn stands on the mound rubbing up the baseball with t same intensity we saw in the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy does it, Ricky. We're only four  down. We're still in this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry if you're off the plate  on a few pitches. Doesn't hurt to  put the fear of God in a hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods and continues to grind the ball as Pepper and Taylor leave. The Yankee Hitter steps in. Vaughn winds and fires a screamer. Taylor has to leap hig to come down with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First pitch is a little high...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Yankee Hitter is slightly unnerved by this pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy kinda wild?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure you got a 30% chance to  survive this at bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER PITCH to the Yankee hitter. It's outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER PITCH to a SECOND YANKEE HITTER. It's low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER PITCH to a THIRD YANKEE HITTER. He has to jump ov it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low, and Vaughn has walked the bases  loaded on twelve straight pitches.  By the laws of probability, you'd  think one of those coulda drifted  over the plate.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLEACHER BAND
dialogues.text: Bobby gives the downbeat and, in honor of Vaughn, the thr men stand to pound out a version of "Wild Thing" on the t toms. Bobby does the vocal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild thing, You make my heart sing,  You walk everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pepper has reached the mound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay kid. I think we got 'em scared  enough now. Time to get a few of 'em  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods. He's plenty upset with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just relax, and keep the arm up on  top. Gotta throw strikes. No place  at the inn for this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Vaughn a pat on the butt, and goes back to the  dugout. The Yankee hitter, HAYWOOD, stands in. He's the first bas who tagged Hayes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Taylor, what you doin' back up  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't cut it in the Mexican League.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn, determined to throw a strike, winds and delivers. The ball is a perfect strike, right down the middle. Haywood crushes it to deep left field. Vaughn drops his h not even bothering to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball lands in the second deck; a grand slam home run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brown) Looked like a strike anyway. You  want me to go get him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, let's see how he reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn paces around on the mound, rubbing up the ball. Th next hitter, COLEMAN, steps in. Vaughn gets up on the rub his face set. He winds up and fires one right into Colema back. Coleman goes down in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least he hit what he was aimin'  at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you can go get him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both benches are up on the dugout steps ready to come out The only thing holding them back is that Coleman is being tended to by the trainer. The home plate umpire thumbs Vaughn out of the game. Vaug comes down to protest, but Pepper quickly grabs him and  hurries him off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, kid. As soon as Coleman gets  up, he's gonna be lookin' for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman finally gets to his feet, still a little shaken. looks around for Vaughn, but he's already disappeared int the dugout. Coleman walks down to first under his own pow Brown signals for a new pitcher and the players on both s begin to return to the benches.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: walking alone down the tunnel to the locker room. He angr knocks one of the overhead light bulbs out with his glove

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE IN THE PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: He now has five empty cups next to the mike, plus a near- empty bottle of Jack Daniel's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, a tough start for the Erie  warriors, as they drop a heartbreaker  to the Yankees, nine to nothing. The  Post Game Show was brought to you  by... (searching for the  paper) Christ. I can't find it. The hell  with it. This is Harry Doyle saying  good night, everybody, and Happy  Hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that Doyle passes out on his face.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL PHELPS
dialogues.text: in her private box at the stadium. With her are Donovan a Butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up to leave) We're off to a good start, gentlemen.  Let's keep it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We GO TO Donovan. He watches Rachel go in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn are in a booth, having a beer. V is still in a funk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I was horse shit tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only thing you got to be sorry about  was hittin' Coleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wanted to send a message, it  shoulda been to Haywood. He hit the  damn homer. Coleman was just picking  his nose in the on-deck circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the other stuff. It coulda  happened to anybody. Besides, Haywood  didn't hit it that good. That ball  wouldn't have been out of a lotta  parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeh, name one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Yellowstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn just looks at Taylor a second and then smiles in s of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Taylor walking up the steps and through the massiv front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP Taylor making his way past the circulation des He glances around and finds what he's looking for: Lynn,  talking to one of the reference librarians. She finishes conversation and turns, to find herself face to face with Taylor. She's wearing her tortoise-shell glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed) Jake, you shouldn't have come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wonderin' why you'd give an  old friend a bum phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk in my office, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk in your office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn starts to walk. We'll FOLLOW them as they make their way through the library. Lynn tries to keep the conversat hushed. Taylor could give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I don't think it's a good  idea for us to see each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have anything in common.  Sometimes I wonder if we ever did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talkin' about? We were  both athletes, world class, hot for  each other. What more can you have  in common?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stopped bein' an athlete three  years ago. Books are my life now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake suppresses a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare laugh, Jake. In two  years I've put together one of the  best special collections departments  in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it? You're still sore I  never read Moby Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never read anything I asked you  to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like what's-his-name at the  restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Tom, and keep your voice  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya see in this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's stable. He's intelligent... and  I've never found him in bed with a  stewardess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 'cause no stewardess would  have him. Wouldn't you rather be  with somebody who's in demand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like always, you don't take  anything seriously. Everything's a  joke to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Lynn, for Christ sake, I'm  just tryin' to loosen things up a  little. I'm gettin' frostbite here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn stops and turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and I are getting married in the  fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor is momentarily floored by the revelation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? That's crazy, Lynn. I got plans  for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking again) What plans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna play another a year or  two, then we go to Hawaii, and have  a couple kids who grow up to be  Olympic champions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping again) How can you think stuff like that? I  haven't seen you in two years. You  never even wrote me a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Lynn, but I wasn't exactly  proud of my situation. C'mon, you  didn't think about me at all since I  been gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking again) Not so loud, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the three nights we spent  on the beach in Vera Cruz? You have  nights like that with Mr. Briefcase?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping again) What about the night you had in  Detroit with Miss Dairy Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the large reading room now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I supposed to do? She bet  me fifty bucks she had a better body  than you. I had to defend your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whirling on him and  exploding) What a bunch of bullshit! (exasperated) I have a much better body than she  does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this the whole reading room turns around and stares her. Lynn is mortified by her outburst. Taylor tries to s it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing the library  patrons) She's right. Take it from me, she  really does. I mean Miss Dairy Queen  has quantity, I give her that, but  the, ah, quality just isn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice job, Jake. Lynn is still mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many think Lynn oughta give me  another shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the hands in the room shoot up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ayes have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking off again) You haven't changed at all, have  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I have or I wouldn't be  here. C'mon, Lynn, I don't wanna do  time for things that happened years  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back to him) I'm sorry, Jake. You'll always be  the little boy who wouldn't grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn starts off for her office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn, wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn continues on into her office. As the door closes, we TO Taylor's forlorn face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is in closed-door session with Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quarter of the season's gone, we're  15 and 24, seven games out of first.  Our attendance is just below 180,000.  That's bad, but not bad enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Projected over the whole season, we  stand to wind up 36 games under .500  and 28 out of first. That should be  bad enough for anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finished 24 out last year and  still drew 890,000. When school's  out for the summer, attendance is  liable to rise. Plus, this team is  showing signs of improvement. I didn't  think we'd win 15 games all year.  Any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On how we can get worse? (sarcastic) How about a series of fines for good  play? Maybe a $30,000 bonus to the  guy chosen Least Valuable Player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no laughing matter, Donovan. (pause) I think maybe the problem is we're  coddling these guys too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Donovan wonders what she means by that, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP Taylor, Hayes, Vaughn and the other Indians co down a corridor to their plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with this? We never leave  from this terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the other one's jammed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come through the gate where they see two American  Airlines jets on the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the jets) Which one is ours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gateman points off-screen. Suddenly, an old DC-3, wit the Indian logo on it, pulls into frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one was obviously bought from the military. The seat are 40's Army issue, and the ribs of the fuselage are exp The plane is bobbing and lurching through a ferocious sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Lou?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front office says it's an economy  measure, 'cause we're not drawin'  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they certainly have spared  every expense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP Cerrano crossing himself. Harris sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so now you come around. (pointing up) He's not fooled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes sits petrified in his chair, his knuckles whitening the arm rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the stewardess, Vaughn. I need  one of those bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any stewardesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if there's any pilots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP Doyle doing the play-by-play of the Indians' n game. He can barely keep his eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two down, top of the ninth. Last  chance for the red and blue.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
