dialogues.text: The Brewer pitcher delivers and a Cleveland player hits a ground ball to the Brewer Second Baseman who throws him o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouncing ball to second. This should  be it. Collins up with it, on to  first, and the game is over.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: in the press box again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the Sons of Geronimo, still  suffering a bit from propeller lag,  are nipped by the Tigers tonight, 7  to 0. The only excitement for the  tribe provided by Rick Vaughn who  set an American League record by  throwing four wild pitches in one  inning. Congratulations, Rick. For  the Tigers, 5 runs, 9 hits, and no  errors. For the Indians, one run,  and let's see, one hit. (to his Stat Man) Is that all we got, one fucking hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) You can't say "fuckin'" on the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Nobody's  listening anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorn and Harris are at one table; Taylor and Vaughn at on across the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you got lined up tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we? Kansas City, right?  Gotta be Arlene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have to. She knows when I'm in  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm about ready to turn in. I've  anesthetized my knees enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUY from the bar approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Vaughn, can I have  your autograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... yeh... sure. (signing) My first autograph. I couldn't give  these away a couple weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your record on the news. You  made their Hall of Shame.  Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a celebrity now, Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you had to do somethin'  good to be a celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you do it colorfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the door) What'd I tell ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We GO TO the door to find ARLENE standing with two friend RENE and VICKI. ARLENE is a looker alright, 27, and serio built. She cases the room, spies Dorn and comes over to h table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Rodger. This is Vicki and Rene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, doll. This is Steve Harris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your buddy Gant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Vaughn) They cut him to make room for bristle  boy over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over at Vaughn) Is that Vaughn, the guy they call  Wild Thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in disgust) Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's kinda cute. They say he could  be a big star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talkin' about? He  couldn't find the plate if it was  magnetized. He won't last the year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struck out five in a row before  the wild pitches. (taking her leave) Maybe I'll check him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing her) Wait a minute, you're with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor watches this exchange from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember you makin' any date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do I have to make a date?  Who's been showin' you this town the  last three years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ancient history, Rodger. I gotta  look out for myself now. I don't  have to be a slave to no .235 hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARLENE pulls away and heads for the jukebox as Dorn seeth She punches a button and we hear X's version of "WILD THI ARLENE sashays right up to Vaughn in time with the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild Thing, you make my heart sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARLENE knows how to make the big entrance. Vaughn's sligh overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: DORN
dialogues.text: taking this all in from across the room. Taylor comes up  next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess we're over with, eh, Dorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself, Taylor. I got a  couple good years left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP Taylor in his seat, glasses on, reading someth by the light of a flashlight rigged up to the back of his seat. We MOVE to reveal it -- the Classics Illustrated co book of "Moby Dick." Hayes wanders by, an air-sick bag hanging around his neck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Moby Dick?" What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of the masterpieces of  American literature, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn put you on to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're goin' to a club tonight.  You wanna come along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I got some more reading to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor indicates a stack of Classic Comics next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you got a test or somethin'?  Why don't you just go over and see  her? Maybe she'll let you slide on a  couple of these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might if I knew where she lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy. Tail her home from the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean sit in a car and wait for  her to come out? That's kinda  juvenile, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if that had  anything to do with  it) Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor sits in his car, across the street from the employ entrance of the library. He scrunches down a bit as Lynn  comes out of the building and heads for her car. She gets and we...

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS OF LYNN
dialogues.text: driving through the city with Taylor following at a discr distance. Finally, Lynn pulls up outside an expensive-loo townhouse. Taylor pulls up further down the street and wa her go inside, debating whether to go in after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor's having a beer, still trying to decide whether to see her or not.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: pulling up outside the townhouse he saw Lynn go into. He  goes up the stairs and knocks on the door. Lynn answers, looking more dressed up than when she left library. She's surprised to see Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Lynn, I'm sorry I followed you  home but I wanna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurried) This isn't my place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose place is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Lynn can answer, Tom appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there, love? (spying Taylor) Oh, Mr. Taylor, right? (pointedly) I remember you from the restaurant.  Lynn's told me a lot about you. Why  don't you come in for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, that's o.k., I got some things  to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, he's gotta be goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, come on in for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Taylor can beg off further, Tom ushers him inside closes the door. In the room are two other couples: ARTHU HOLLOWAY, a senior partner in Tom's firm and his wife CLA and BRENT BOWDEN, another lawyer in the firm and a  contemporary of Tom's. His wife is JANICE. This is a very upscale group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, everybody, this is Jake  Taylor. (making the intros) Jake, Arthur and Claire Holloway  Brent and Janice Bowden. Jake is a  professional baseball player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polite nods from the group, except for Janice, who seems  somewhat intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Jake, what brings you here this  evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, ah, just had a couple books I  wanted to discuss with Lynn. I thought  this was her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it soon will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, I heard you guys were engaged.  Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor sticks out his hand. Tom's not sure whether Taylor putting him on or not. He shakes anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. What can I get you to  drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom goes off to get the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What team do you play for, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here in Cleveland? I didn't know  they still had a team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, we have uniforms and everything.  It's really great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Jake his  beer) They're last right now, but hopefully  moving up, eh, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom clinks his glass with Jake's beer, the slight  condescension in his manner not lost on Taylor. Lynn is  uncomfortable with this whole situation. Janice moves a b closer to Taylor. It's obvious she finds him attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm told that baseball players make  very good salaries these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on how good they are, I  guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How good are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn is irritated by Janice's directness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make the League minimum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and the others react as if Taylor's just announced a  death in the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was one of the best in baseball  until he had problems with his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is somewhat surprised by Lynn's quick defense of Taylor, including Lynn herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do when your  career ends? I mean you can't play  baseball forever, can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin'll come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I was thinkin' of goin'  to Hawaii, and having a couple of  kids who grow up to be Olympic  champions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really. In what event?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimming. Maybe the two hundred meter  Individual Medley. I figure it oughta  be big by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack just nods. He never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the girl picked out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, but I wasn't smart enough to  hold on to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn's eyes drop to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to be an athlete, didn't  you, Lynn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not wanting to pursue  it) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Two Hundred Individual medley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alternate on the '80 Olympic Team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense silence settles on the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta be goin'. Nice to have  met you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor exchanges a quick glance with Lynn and heads for t door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me walk you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom accompanies Taylor to the door, out of earshot of the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know if I land a good  job. I know you're concerned about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, well, I just wanted Lynn to  know what she would've had ahead of  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom sticks out his hand. The two men shake to keep up  appearances for their onlookers across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Suck my dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn and Hayes are watching a soap opera on an old blac and white TV. Pepper pops his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou wants to see you down at the  office, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn looks somewhat apprehensively at Hayes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown is lost in thought at his desk. Vaughn appears at t door like a boy expecting a spanking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon in, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn comes in and takes a seat. He's worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick, I'm not gonna beat around the  bush here. You got a great arm, one  of the best I've ever seen, but your  control hasn't come around like we  hoped it would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods contritely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, there are a lotta pitchers that  started out wild and, after workin'  it out in the minors, for a while,  went on to great careers. (pointing to a picture  on the wall) Take Sandy Koufax there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn looks at the picture on the wall. He squints sligh Brown notices it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Koufax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind Koufax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown quickly prints some big letters on a legal pad and  goes to stand about fifteen feet from Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read these letters, starting at the  top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn balks a second and then concentrates on the pad,  squinting. Unsettled, he squints harder. He even tries cl one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't read it, can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna send me to the minors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, Hayes, Vaughn and the others are dressing out for the game. Vaughn is wearing his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These things make me look ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop in the bucket, Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Cerrano is sharpening a long knife at his lock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin and cigarettes not enough for Jo- Buu. I still can no hit curva ball  for sheet. I hafta make a sacrifice  to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacrifice? You mean like something  living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. I kill unborn children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not while I'm here you're not. That's  murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cerrano pulls the unborn chicken out of his pocket -- a c store bought egg. Harris is a little embarrassed at his  outburst. Cerrano touches the egg to his forehead, then places it o his altar. In one swift motion he slams the knife down on it, cutting it into two perfect halves. Taylor and the ot are agape at a knife sharp enough to do this. As the yolk spreads out on the altar, Brown emerges from his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's hit the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locker room quickly empties, leaving one man behind - Harris. He looks around to make sure everyone is gone, th tiptoes over to Cerrano's locker. Screwing up his courage he picks up Jo-Buu's cup of gin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's looking at ya, Jo-Buu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolts it down, then backs into the middle of the room, waiting at the ready, as if half-expecting a bolt of  lightning. When nothing happens, he gloats at the fetish  doll in triumph.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: strutting out of the dugout, feeling like a million bucks As he emerges onto the field, a Hitter in the batting cag swings and misses, the bat slipping out of his hands. Awa it flies, whirling off down the third base line in a wide arc. It hits Harris in the back of the head and knocks hi cold.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: watching the game from the dugout, a zip-lock baggie full ice-cubes strapped to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the ninth, two down, man on  first and the Indians clinging to a  one run lead. VAUGHAN, one out away  from his first major league victory...

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHAN
dialogues.text: Vaughn, wearing his new glasses, paces the mound nervousl He goes to the rosin bag, wipes his brow, shakes out his  arm. Finally up on the rubber, he gets the sign from Tayl goes to his stretch, checks the runner and fires to the p

dialogues.speaker: THE OAKLAND BATTER
dialogues.text: swings and hits a grounder between third and short. Dorn  moves to his left, but the ball goes past his glove and i left field. There is some question as to whether Dorn rea gave it a full effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouncing ball, Dorn can't get to it,  into left field, base hit. Clarke  digging around second, he'll make it  to third, and the A's have runners  at the corners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn stomps around on the mound, obviously upset. He gl at Dorn a beat before getting back on the mound. Dorn's f is non-commital. Brown paces in the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to go get him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's come this far. Let's see if  he can finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle downs a little more rum and coke in the press box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn in a little trouble here, but  I'll tell ya, these Cleveland fans  are great. Listen to them get behind  Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle imitates the sound of a crowd cheering with his own voice, punctuated by whistles and clapping.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLEACHER BAND
dialogues.text: Thelma calmly knits her blanket with the scores of all th Indians' games stitched into it, the Madame La Farge of  Cleveland. The boys, however, are a little restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need some defense here. Maybe we  oughta do a wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Indians don't do waves. Let's  keep this thing pure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What harm could it do?

dialogues.speaker: REXMAN
dialogues.text: The next Oakland hitter, steps in. Taylor flashes a sign. Vaughn comes to the stretch and delivers. High, ball one. The runner on first goes down to second without a throw, pitch being too tough to handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runner goes, high, Taylor has no  play. The go-ahead and potential  winning run is in scoring position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor walks out in front of the plate to throw the ball  back to Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the runners, Ricky, get this  guy at the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor goes back behind the dish. Vaughn gets up on the  rubber. He winds and comes to the plate. Way high this ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High ball two, and the crowd doesn't  like that call one bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle imitates the sound of a crowd booing. Taylor, meanw has gone out to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's get nasty here, Rick.  You know he's lookin' for this pitch.  Gotta come up with somethin' studly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' Dorn. Game shoulda been over  by now. Dorn coulda had that ball.  He tanked it on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the California Penal  League, Vaughn. We're professionals  here. We don't tank a play for  personal reasons, so cut the crybaby  shit. You've pitched a helluva game.  You wanna finish it, don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you give me a strike on this  pitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, but I don't know if there'll be  much on it. My arm feels like jello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just make sure it's over the plate.  I want him to swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time I did that, the guy  hit one that hasn't landed yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor starts back toward the plate, and then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I been meaning to ask  you. Why'd you steal that car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you might think about takin'  in a movie or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn permits himself a little smile and release from th tension. Taylor smiles back, and trots off toward the pla

dialogues.speaker: THE BLEACHER BAND
dialogues.text: Bobby and Vic are doing a two-man wave. When one sits dow the other stands up.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: has settled in behind the plate now. He starts talking to the batter, Rexman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva situation we got goin' here,  huh, Rexman? Two on, two out, you're  down by a run in the ninth. You got  a chance to be a hero on national  television, so whatever you do, don't  blow it. They'll be callin' you a  gutless choke artist all over America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rexman shoots Taylor a wicked glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a free agent at the end of  the year. Not much demand for gutless  choke artists. What are you hittin'  now? .230? .240?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, nice average. Uh oh, on second  thought, that still means you got a  seven outta ten chance of goin' in  the dumper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rexman, slightly irritated, backs out of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, will ya, Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I can understand not wantin' to  talk about baseball when your nuts  are in a vice like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rexman gets back in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I saw your wife at the  Capri Lounge last night. Hell of a  dancer. You must be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rexman is trying to ignore Taylor, but failing badly. Tay flashes a sign to Vaughn. Vaughn goes into his windup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that guy she was with... I mean  I'm sure he's a close personal friend  of yours and all, but tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn releases his pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why was he wearing her panties on  his head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rexman, completely unnerved, takes a feeble swing and hit high pop-up out in front of the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh, Rexie, I don't think that  one's got the distance. Maybe if the  wind comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor moves out two steps and makes the catch easily, en the game. Taylor rushes out to congratulate Vaughn. The players exc handshakes and high fives, as Brown watches from the dugo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's startin' to come together,  Pepper. It's startin' to come  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor pulls up outside and walks up to the door. Suzanne Dorn's wife, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hi, Jake, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Suzanne, can I have a quick  word with Rodger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, c'mon in, he's in the den.  I'll get some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Taylor into the luxurious den, where we find Do watching his wide screen TV in a smoking jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jake, old boy, what brings you  out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanta tell ya somethin', but  I didn't want to do it in front of  the whole team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like nails) I don't know what your problem is,  but... (bending close to  Dorn) ...if I ever see you tank another  play like you did tonight, I'll cut  off your nuts and stuff 'em down  your fuckin' throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorn looks at Taylor for some sign that he's kidding. He  doesn't get one. Taylor turns and walks on out, as we go to Dorn's stunned face. Suzanne walks in with a tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indians are undressing after practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell are we havin' practice  during the All-Star break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard the Big Lady upstairs ordered  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hotter than shit in here. What  happened to the air conditioning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Brown, naked and dragging from the heat. He  approaches the whirlpool and turns on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dorn) Oh man, this old body can use a soak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. It's not workin' again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown flips on a switch. The whirlpool makes some grindin noises and then quits altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, I thought they were gonna  replace this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harris shouts over from the showers where he's just turne on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's no hot water in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at it again. I've had it with  this nickel and dime stuff. (storming out of the  training room) I'm gonna get the Bitch on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown is stopped short by the sight of Rachel Phelps stan in the middle of the locker room as various unclad player dive for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see the Bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think you oughta cover  yourself with a towel first, Mr.  Brown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any towels, and I'm too  old to be diving under benches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can take it if you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the new whirlpool  we were supposed to get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revenue problems have forced us to  cut back on equipment. We'll simply  have to fix the old one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fixed it six times already. And  now there's no hot water in the  showers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pipes in this building are old  and rusted. We're replacing them,  but it's a long, expensive process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to keep my players  healthy with cold water and no therapy  equipment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your players will just have to get a  little tougher. What are they, a  bunch of pansies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately, 30 arms shoot up behind her in the Italian " yours" gesture. She turns around, but by then the players have quickly returned to normal positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over 162 games even tough guys get  sprains, sore arms, muscle pulls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only temporary. Besides, these  guys weren't playing that good when  the equipment was workin'. If I could  get anybody to come and watch this  team, none of this would be necessary.  You oughta be grateful I can still  pay your salaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, Rachel turns and walks out. Brown and the othe can only watch her go.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: SPORTSCASTER ROSS FARMER
dialogues.text: On the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you haven't noticed, and  judging by attendance, you haven't,  the Indians, that thought-to-be  hopeless collection of has-been's  and never-will-be's is actually  approaching the .500 mark, and with  it, semi-respectability. Nothing to  write home about, to be sure, but at  least we don't have to cover our  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, Vic and Johnny are at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, they could be a lot worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Business Executive is talking with a friend while wor out on the Nautilus machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, I may have underestimated  this team a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Longshoremen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, these guys aren't so fuckin'  bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Groundskeepers are repairing the pitcher's mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in subtitles) They're still shitty.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown storms out of the dugout, doing his best to look  incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah shit, here comes Lou. Gimme a  break, Mel. I gotta get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, kick some dirt on me. The  Commissioner'll buy that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor begins kicking dirt on Wingo's shoes, ala Billy Ma Wingo takes a dramatic hop, skip and jump and gives Taylo the heave-ho thumb just as Brown arrives. Wingo turns awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wingo) Hey, don't you go anywhere. I wanna  have a few words with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown grabs Taylor and pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) What are we arguin' about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling as if he  wanted to get at  Wingo) Fucker called that a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the one that was a foot  outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor breaks away and starts back to the dugout. Playing to the hilt, he throws his glove and mask to the ground o the way. Meanwhile, Brown is going jaw to jaw with Wingo, outraged the call. Brown pulls a carrot out of his back pocket, an offers it to Wingo, who immediately thumbs him out.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: leaving her seat and starting up the aisle. Taylor comes up the stairs from the locker room, still in full uniform. He emerges onto the box level to see Lynn  disappearing down the ramp toward the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: in the parking lot. As she goes to unlock her car, Taylor looks around hurriedly for some kind of vehicle to follow her in. He bangs on the bullpen gates and is admitted by the guar Inside is the Bullpen car, a souped-up golf cart with a b shaped like a batting helmet. Taylor hops in and roars ou after Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn comes out of the dressing room into the pool area,  deserted this time of night. She wears a racing suit, but lets her hair hang free. The pool glows like a sheet of  emerald glass. She shakes down a beat, curls her toes aro the coping, slowly bends at the waist, and then launches  into a full-out racing dive. We watch as she swims a 100 yard individual medley; first the butterfly, then the backstroke, breaststroke and fina freestyle. We condense the time, of course, SHOOTING some underwater, some SLO-MO, as she knives through the water, her hair flowing behind her, an athlete alone with her me The SEQUENCE should convey not only the grace of her stro and her athletic ability, but the fluid beauty of swimmin its synthesis of power and form. As she begins the freestyle leg, another body appears in pool next to her. It's Jake, and he's racing her the fina lap. She immediately responds to the challenge, digging  harder, picking up her kick. They go neck and neck for 20 yards, but Lynn has one more gear and touches him by half body length at the wall. Both are winded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still got that great kick. Just  like the first time I ever saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You follow me here too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, what did you want to see me  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have been at the game  if you didn't want to see me about  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting out of the  pool) I just wanted to see you play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looked good, but you oughta open  your stance a little. They're pitching  you inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try that. You wanna have some  dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I already ate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I forgot your life is different  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting out of the  pool) Thanks for the race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching her go) Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving through the city on her way home. Lynn glances in the rear-view mirror and spots Taylor following her. She  smiles to herself. Taylor, of course, thinks he's gone  undetected. We begin a SHORT SEQUENCE during which Lynn tries to lose Taylor in a chase through Cleveland, car vs. batting helm The logistics will have to be worked out in Cleveland, bu suffice it to say, by the end of the chase she appears to have ditched him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn comes up the stairs, unlocks the apartment door and  steps inside. There's no particular urgency. She feels su she's shaken Taylor. The apartment is full of packing boxes. Tired from the ch Lynn drops her bag on a box and slumps down on the couch. It's obvious she's not all that happy to have lost Taylor She goes to the window and looks down to the street for s sign of him. Seeing nothing, she turns away from the window disappoint and starts back to the couch, when something stops her. I Taylor, standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose place are we at this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) Mine. You follow me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. When I saw you at the game, I  figured you wanted to see me about  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to see you play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looked good, but you oughta open  your stance a little. They're pitchin'  you inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor gives a perfunctory nod. They look at each other a second. There's still plenty there. Taylor begins to come toward her. We hear his cleats on the floor. She backs of but not with real conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I oughta tell you that I'm  moving in with Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' uptown, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not goin' uptown, I just want to  lead a regular life. You know, like  an adult maybe. With a house and a  garden and normal hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I can't lead a regular  life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the life you've had, Jake.  You like hangin' out with the boys,  livin' in hotels, eatin' dinner at  midnight, having girls send you their  underwear in the mail. Remember the  surprise party I threw for you when  you made the All-Star team? You never  showed up, but the doorbell rang  once and we all got quiet and hid  behind the furniture. It was a guy  to serve you with a paternity suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a hoax. The girl was just  trying to get some publicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but you had obviously been with  her. And it happened in front of all  our friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was drownin', Lynn. The endorsements  were dryin' up, my knees were goin',  they were talkin' about sendin' me  down. I was just trying to hold on  to somethin', prove to myself I was  still an All-Star. I don't care about  that anymore. I know I don't have  much time left in baseball. I'm just  a guy trying to put his life back  together. Thinkin' about you was the  only thing that kept me goin' in  Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn looks at him a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come back to you too many times,  Jake. I can't afford to believe you  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn is backed up against a desk now. She could move out doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess this is our last hurrah then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. Did you really read "Moby  Dick?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cover to cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor comes forward to kiss her, tentatively at first. T conversation is interwoven with the slowly deepening inte of their kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom and dad like this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still their favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're unbuttoning each other's shirts now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna be a big wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom doesn't like big weddings. You  coulda read Plot Outlines of 101  Great Novels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At any library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All Saints on Euclid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. Who saved Ishmael at the end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. It was Queequeg's coffin. Am  I invited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want. Maybe you really did  read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their shirts are off now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't change anything, you  know. We were always good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The zipper on your skirt is stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor's spikes come down across her skirt, catching in t material, ripping it from her body and pinning it to the  wood floor. Taylor steps out of the shoe and whisks Lynn OF FRAME. We hold on the skirt, nailed to the floor by th cleats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor wakens and turns over to find Lynn gone. He looks  around but there's no sign of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor comes down the steps, gets in his car, and drives OF FRAME. We HOLD on the SHOT, and...

dialogues.speaker: THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Taylor's car pulls INTO FRAME. He gets out and goes up th steps. There's one light on in the apartment window. Tayl comes up to the door and knocks. Getting no answer, he pu it open to find that the apartment is completely empty. J bare hardwood floor. Taylor stands forlorn in the center the room a beat, then walks on out, switching off the ove light as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donovan is present once again. Rachel does not look pleas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my worst fears have been  confirmed. We're 60 and 60, nine  games out of first, and only two out  of the first division. Who do those  guys think they are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you just have to accept the  fact that they're not as bad as you'd  hoped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to accept anything. Our  attendance is only beginning to rise.  If we can force a losing streak for  a week or two, we can still turn  this thing around. The fans are used  to losers here. At the first sign of  a slump they'll give up on this team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left to do? You've taken away  everything you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up a decrepit old Greyhound bus coming down the  highway, belching smoke like a diesel semi. On the side w see the visage of Chief Wahoo and the words "Indian Expre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete with all the luxuries of the average school bus. Temple is looking at a memo from Rachel Phelps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memo says we'll only be usin' this  for short trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing we don't play anybody in  Europe.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR AND HAYES
dialogues.text: Taylor is staring out the window, still morose about Lynn leaving. A stack of Classics Illustrated comics sits next him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I borrow one of those, man? They  don't have any magazines on this  bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, go ahead. I think my reading  days are over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macbeth. This a good one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to his stack  of Classics) These are all Hall of Famers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayes is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian Express makes its way through the streets of N York, enroute to the Indian's hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that now most of the team is reading classic comic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dorn) I'll trade you Song of Hiawatha for  The Deerslayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I'm not into Song of Hiawatha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then, how about Crime and  Punishment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, that sounds pretty good. That's  a detective story, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus slows down and pulls over to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it. The Sheffield Arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players all crowd to the window to get a glimpse of t hotel. Hotel is actually overstating it. This place is on cut below the YMCA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if we can survive any  more of these economy measures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn coming into their  dilapidated hotel room. Peeling walls and ceilings, ricke furniture, rusted bathroom fixtures. Taylor sprawls down one of the cots. It collapses on the floor in a cloud of  dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn is on the mound warming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Ricky Vaughn, roughed up in his  only other appearance against the  Yankees, will see what he can do  with the Bronx Bombers this time.  Vaughn, after a slow start, has come  on lately and now leads the American  League in strikeouts with 221.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn finishes his warmups. As Taylor pumps the ball dow to second, Vaughn hears a voice from the Yankee dug-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, jailbird!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn glances over and sees that one of the Yankees is  dressed in a striped prison uniform. He also wears long  earrings, high heels, and of course, glasses. Vaughn trie to ignore the guy, but his concentration is broken. Vaughn steps up on the rubber for his first pitch. He win and fires. The Yankee LEADOFF HITTER rips a one-hopper to the wall in right center. Hayes runs it down and guns it  back to the infield to hold the guy to a double. The conv whoops it up. Vaughn gets back up on the rubber. As he comes to the str he catches sight of the convict again. The guy is doing a pantomime, sneaking up to a car and picking the lock, muc to the delight of his teammates. Vaughn throws his pitch the dirt and all the way to the backstop. The runner on s goes to third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing the ball  back) C'mon, Rick baby, settle down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn gets ready again. The convict finishes picking the lock and then is suddenly arrested. He puts his hands aga the wall and spreads his legs for a weapons check, cracki up the whole bench. Vaughn is getting a little steamed. H next pitch is hammered into left for a single, scoring a  run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: throwing pitches, followed by:

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: of the THIRD HITTER lining a double down the right field  line, the FOURTH HITTER a triple off the center field wal and the FIFTH HITTER a single to right. The scoreboard no reads 4 to 0 Yankees. Taylor comes out to talk to Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem, Rick? You're  throwin' basketballs up there. That  guy in the dugout botherin' you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget him. Worry about the guys  carryin' bats. C'mon, Ricky, let's  get nasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods as Taylor trots back behind the plate. Vaughn gets set again as his old nemesis, Haywood, steps  into the batter's box. Haywood has a sly smile on his fac As Vaughn comes to his stretch, the convict goes back int his act. He's in jail now, struggling against the bars.  Finally he bends over and grabs his ankles, while one of teammates humps up against him, pretending to bugger him. This sends the Yankee bench into hysterics. Vaughn has lost it now. He fires to the plate and Haywood creams another tape measure job into the upper deck. Haye doesn't even bother to run back to the wall. He just watc it go. 6-0 Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought now that Vaughn had some  control, he was ready for the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown makes his way to the mound to take Vaughn out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Vaughn pitches in some tough  luck here as the Yankees put together  as few squib hits and take a 6-0  lead.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: in the press box. The stadium below is empty, the grounds crew covering the infield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the Indians made a gallant  comeback today, but fell one run  short as the Yankees held on for a 6- 5 victory, although they didn't do  squat after the first inning. Anyway,  if the bus makes it here from the  hotel we'll be on at 7:30 tomorrow  night. Till then, this is Harry Doyle,  saying so long, everybody, and Happy  Hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown is alone in the bar having a drink. A figure sits d on the stool next to him. It's Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I join you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised to see him) Donovan. Hell no. What are you doin'  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to get out on the road.  You damn near pulled one out today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday we'll figure out how to beat  those guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, you've done a helluva job  this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty and sixty-one is hardly a  helluva job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this club it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, when I first got to camp I  figured this team had no chance. I  was just hopin' we'd win enough that  I could stay on and really start to  build something here. But there's a  lotta talent on this club, Charlie.  The veterans are starting to play  back to form and the rookies are  developing faster than I thought.  There's two or three potential all- stars in there. I think we're a first  division team right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really believe that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it. All we need is something  to bring it all together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel Phelps would never allow that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't want you in the first  division. She doesn't even want you  in Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Brown's incredulous face, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are all gathered around, obviously having bee called together by Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing the group) I got somethin' I think you oughta  know about. I wouldn't have known  about it myself if Charlie Donovan  hadn't told me, although I shoulda  guessed it from everything that's  happened. It seems that Mrs. Phelps  doesn't think too highly of our worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take several CUTS OF FACES around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She put this team together because  she thought we'd be bad enough to  finish dead last, knockin' attendance  down to the point where she could  move the team to Miami. (pause) And get rid of all of us for better  personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, Vaughn, Hayes, Dorn, and the others can hardly be what they're hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even you, Dorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence descends on the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, Phelps thinks we're  all dinks. That we don't belong in  the big leagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we don't finish last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll replace you with somebody who  will. After this season, you'll all  be sent back to the minors or given  your outright release. (pause) So, all we're gonna get is this one  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor surveys the bowed heads around the room. He stands address the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about the rest of you,  but I've been playin' baseball since  I was five years old. I've had some  good years and some years to forget.  I've burned out my knees... I don't  think I have three fingers that work  right... I've lost most of the money  I made and baseball has messed up my  personal life from time to time. But  I know one thing... I can still play  this game a little. And I'd like to  know who in this room thinks they're  the kinda bum Mrs. Phelps is lookin'  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes dart around the room, then come back to Taylor. No h are raised...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, I guess there's only one  thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Win the whole fuckin' thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take CUTS of the startled faces of the players. As the idea sinks in, they begin to come to life. MUSIC begins a we're into a...

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: detailing the newly-motivated Indians' drive for the penn and the "Pennant Fever" it creates in Cleveland. We begin with...

dialogues.speaker: BROWN
dialogues.text: hanging a full size blowup of Rachel Phelps on the locker room wall. In the picture she's pointing as if out at the players, and a bubble above her head says, "YOU GUYS STIN A set of designer clothes, of the type Rachel wears, have been superimposed on the picture. The clothes are divided into 32 pull-off squares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure it's gonna take 32 more  victories to win this thing. Every  time we win, we peel a square.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: coming out of an elevator in the Turk, with a wheelbarrow full of dirt. We pan him down the hall, where we see a di sliding area he's been building up.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: leading off a makeshift base in the hall of the Turk. As  Vaughn tosses a ball up in the air, Hayes takes off down hall toward another base on the dirt sliding area. Vaughn catches the ball and rifles a throw down to Taylor who puts the tag on the sliding Hayes. Cerrano, who's ump calls Hayes out. Hayes jumps up and argues vociferously,  hopping around in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: PEPPER
dialogues.text: hitting one rocket-shot ground ball after another at Dorn Some bounce off his chest and arms, but Dorn stays in fro of every one.

dialogues.speaker: DORN
dialogues.text: taking off his shirt in the locker room. His chest is a m of welts and bruises.

dialogues.speaker: CERRANO
dialogues.text: "polishing" his bats with black shoe polish and a brush.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: taking batting practice late at night. He attacks the bal swing after swing.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: taking his stretch with a man on first, and firing to the plate. The Batter swings and misses for strike three, whi the Runner on first breaks for second. TAYLOR rifles a th down to second nailing the Runner for a double play.

dialogues.speaker: DORN
dialogues.text: taking a hot smash off his chest. He picks it up and guns the runner down.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: stealing home, as the opposing Pitcher tries frantically hurry his windup. Hayes slides across safely, hooking to infield side. He jumps up and punches the air with his fi

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: nailing up the pair of black gloves he used to steal home above his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross Farmer, microphone in hand, stands in front of a bla bonfire. A large crowd cheers as various people throw doo on the blaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to TV camera) You remember bra burning in the '70's,  well, the newest thing in Cleveland  is doormat burning as Indian fans  are standing up and saying "We won't  be stepped on anymore".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: blowing fast balls by hitter.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: with Donovan next to her, watching all this good play in  disgust.

dialogues.speaker: AN ANGEL HITTER
dialogues.text: lining a single to center. Cerrano charges it and fires t the plate as a Runner tries to score from second. Just as Taylor catches the ball, he's once again knocked flat by Runner. This time he lies still a beat, and then an arm c up holding the ball. The Umpire thumbs the Runner out.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: late at night, sitting head-down in the outboard motor  whirlpool. He's hurting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP three Teenage Girls walking down the street we T-shirts that say WILD THING--I THINK I LOVE YOU. A Black Kid comes by wearing black gloves on each hand. As he pas he holds up one finger signifying Number One. The Girls r the signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Business Executive passes his secretary's desk, gives her some instructions, and goes into his office. As soon he's out of sight, she opens her drawer and slips the ear from a portable radio into her ear. OVER, we hear the Ind BROADCAST.

dialogues.speaker: THE EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: inside his office. He opens his desk drawer and pulls out earplug. He's also listening to the game.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stripper is wearing a squaw costume, with black glove and a WILD THING T-shirt. Several members of the audience have radio earplugs on.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: of squares of leopard skin fabric being peeled away. Unde one is revealed a section of bare hip and thigh. Under  another, a navel. Under still another, the edge of a bare breast and arm.

dialogues.speaker: THE INDIAN TEAM
dialogues.text: all dressed in tuxedos, posed "team picture" style on the infield of Municipal Stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison) Hello, do you know us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a Major League baseball team,  but since we haven't won a pennant  in thirty years, nobody recognizes  us, not even in our own hometown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we carry the American  Express card. No matter how far out  of first we are, it keeps us from  getting shut out at our favorite  hotels and restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you're looking for some big  league clout, apply for the little  green home run hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what it's done for us. People  still don't recognize us, but... (whispering) ...we're in the first division now.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: sliding across home plate in his tuxedo and stopping IN F He holds up an American Express card in a black-gloved ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American Express card. Don't  steal home without it.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS OF FANS
dialogues.text: filing into Cleveland Municipal Stadium. Tickets being ri programs sold, etc.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: swinging and hitting a home run into the left field seats

dialogues.speaker: THE BLEACHER BAND
dialogues.text: beating the tom-toms and whooping it up. The SHOT WIDENS reveal they're no longer alone in the stands.

dialogues.speaker: HAYES
dialogues.text: nailing up another pair of gloves above his head. There a a lot of them up there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the road again. Everyone's asleep except Taylor who li across his seat, heating pads on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: THE LONGSHOREMEN, (POSSIBLE OMIT)
dialogues.text: watching TV in a Cleveland working-class bar. Also cheeri the Indians are several punk and heavy metal kids, their  faces painted with Indian war paint. Strange bedfellows.

dialogues.speaker: CERRANO
dialogues.text: hitting a prodigious home run onto the roof.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: standing up to cheer Cerrano's homer, then remembering he with Rachel. He sits down apologetically. Rachel watches events on the field with a face of cold steel.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: hitting a double into the right centerfield alley with tw runners on. Hayes, the trailing runner, catches up with the lead runn and they reach the plate at about the same time, one slid around the Catcher one way, one around the other. Both score as the Catcher tries to tag both and gets neit

dialogues.speaker: FANS IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: going wild, while the Indian mascot dances on top of the  dugout.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: The program in progress is suddenly interrupted by a Spor Break logo appearing on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We interrupt this program to bring  you the following special bulletin.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS FARMER
dialogues.text: live outside the Indian's locker room. He wears a headdre warpaint, and a Wild Thing T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, everybody. The  incredible has happened. The Indians  have finished the regular season in  a first place tie with the New York  Yankees on the strength of a 4-2 win  over the Tigers in Detroit today.  There will be a one-game playoff  here in Cleveland the day after  tomorrow to decide the Eastern  Division Championship, the Indians  having won the coin flip held just  moments ago in the American League  office. We'll have further details  on the news at 11, but for now, get  your tomahawks ready, Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: A PIECE OF LEOPARD SKIN FABRIC
dialogues.text: We hear cheers as it's ripped away to reveal the photogra image of Rachel's cleavage. We PULL BACK to see the life- size poster is now completely peeled. Rachel stares out a us in a G-string and tassels. The photo is obviously from her showgirl days. General merriment prevails in the locker room. Players sh hands, back slapping, etc. Hayes comes by to exchange  congratulations with Taylor. MUSIC and MONTAGE END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, not bad for a has-been and a  never-will-be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't won anything yet. We still  got one more to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorn comes by Taylor's locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Taylor, there's a coupla drop- dead Annies outside. One of 'em says  she used to know you pretty good.  Brunette, great rack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. What doya say we chat 'em up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without much  enthusiasm) I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, you're not gonna keep moonin'  over that library chick, are you?  Forget her, she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We leave Taylor thinking it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne Dorn is watching the 11 o'clock news. HAL CHARLES holding forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indians are spending the night  in Detroit and will bus back to  Cleveland in the morning. We're going  to go back now to Ross Farmer who's  standing by at the Hotel Stanley  where the Indians are staying in  Detroit. Ross?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene shifts to...

dialogues.speaker: THE LOBBY OF THE STANLEY HOTEL
dialogues.text: where Ross Farmer stands, microphone in hand. Behind him  several players can be seen partying in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Hal. As you can see, the  Indians are in high spirits tonight,  looking forward to their showdown  with the Yankees. Who will start  that game is still a matter of some  conjecture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ross talks, Dorn walks INTO THE FRAME in the far backg with his arm around a YOUNG LOVELY. They're nuzzling and  hugging, unaware they're on camera, albeit in the backgro Suzanne doesn't miss it though. She moves closer to the s to get a better look. Dorn and the Girl get in an elevator together, obviously  going upstairs. As the elevator closes, Suzanne hits the button. She sits there a second in shock, and then her fa begins to harden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor and DARLA are undressing, preparatory to getting i bed. They are definitely no strangers to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still got that black Corvette?  The one that the sound system took  up the whole trunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I had to sell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they gave them to ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not after your knees go bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, you'll be gettin'  a new one now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darla is down to her bra and panties. She puts her leg up the bed to unhook her stockings. Taylor is about to take his pants, but stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darla, I don't think I can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? We did this between  innings once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm just not that guy anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darla looks at him a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned) Happens to the best of them sooner  or later. What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Darla comes out, fully clothed now. Sh turns to say goodbye to Jake, who is still bare-chested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Jake. Too bad. I was gonna  devote a whole chapter to you in my  book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Darla gives Jake a goodbye peck, the elevator door ope across the hall, and out steps Lynn. She's obviously ratt by the sight of Taylor and Darla together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I was in town for a  conference and thought I'd drop by,  but I can see you're busy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that she quickly steps back into the elevator and th doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn, wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor leaps to the elevator door, but it's too late. He  then sprints to the end of the hall and down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: running down the stairs and into the lobby. Seeing no sig of Lynn, he races out the front door to see her pulling o in a taxi. He can only stand and watch her disappear into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PICK UP Vaughn making his way to the back of the bus,  where Brown has his "office" on the last seat. Most of th other players are asleep after a late night of partying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, Rick. I just wanted to tell you  that I'm startin' Harris tomorrow  against the Yankees, even though  it's your turn in the rotation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn says nothing, but he's clearly disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got more experience and a little  better record against the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, sure. Whatever's best for the  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't read anything into it, Rick.  You're one of the guys that got us  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn turns and walks back up the aisle. Brown watches h go, knowing he's still upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian bus pulls up outside the Stadium, where a grou of several thousand fans wait. The players are showered w cheers and applause as they file out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn sits in the bar alone, nursing a beer, still troub by his demotion. He hears a sexy VOICE behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind if I join you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn turns around to see Suzanne Dorn. She's dressed to draw blood, looking better than we've ever seen her. She  slides into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'd be very good company  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Job problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn falls silent. Suzanne stares at him with a devasta combination of sexual heat and tender admiration. She's  pulling out all the stops. Vaughn's a little flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, ah, a ball player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but that's not why I came  over. I don't chase ball players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come over then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're the sexiest man I've  ever laid eyes on, and you look like  you could use a... friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We GO TO Vaughn. Forget it. He's a goner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn has dozed off in the bed. Suzanne, is getting dres Vaughn wakes up as she finishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even get your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne. Suzanne Dorn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (having heard that  name someplace before) Suzanne Dorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Suzanne Dorn. (kissing him on the  forehead) So long. You're a great kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that she walks on out, leaving Vaughn dazed by the  knowledge of who he's just slept with.

dialogues.speaker: THE HALL OUTSIDE VAUGHN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Taylor is coming back from the bathroom down the hall as  Suzanne comes out of Vaughn's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant) Hello, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Suzanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor is amazed by what he's just seen. As soon as Suzan is out of sight, he goes to Vaughn's room and opens the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn is sitting on his bed in a state of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God I didn't know who she  was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor nods that it's all right even though he doesn't be it.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIMO
dialogues.text: pulling up outside the church. Lynn is helped out of the by her Father. As she starts up the steps, she sees that  both sides are lined by the entire Cleveland Indians team uniform. They form an arch of bats as she passes. At the of the steps is Taylor. Lynn stops as her father ushers h mother on into the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I didn't think you'd come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay. (indicating the team) We gotta get to the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck today, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, you too. (pause) Tell me one thing. The night you  came up to my hotel -- was there  really a library conference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I came to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad it didn't work out better. I  just wanna say I'm sorry for all the  things I've put you through over the  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even for last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be sorry for that. Nothing  happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says this with absolute conviction. Despite herself, L senses that he's telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you weren't defending my honor  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have to. She knew she was  outclassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn smiles. He gives her a kiss and watches as she goes  inside. He stands there a long beat, then turns and walks slowly down the steps past his teammates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is looking out at the empty stadium. There's a KNO at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is opened by a Male Secretary and in steps Lou B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Lou, what can I do for ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou puts a folded piece of paper on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to hand in my resignation  before you had a chance to fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you been tryin' to do  with this team. After the season, I  want no part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I knew I could count on Charlie  to tell somebody. I was just afraid  he might take too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you want him to tell  somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'd tell the team, hopefully  getting them mad enough to knock  themselves out trying to prove they  belonged in this league. I think it  worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tryin' to make me believe you  wanted us to win all along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. What about the plane, the  bus, the bad hotels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were broke. We couldn't afford  anything better. Donald left the  team nearly bankrupt. If we'd had  another losing season, I would have  had to sell the team. I knew we  couldn't win with the team we had,  so I decided to bring in new players  and see how they'd do with the proper  motivation. There was never any offer  from Miami. I made it all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I believe any of this?  Now that we're winnin' it's easy for  you to jump on the bandwagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'd really wanted you to lose,  all I had to do was send the best  players back to the minors. But I  didn't, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown has no comeback for this. He knows now that she's  telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this was all an accident?  I personally scouted every member of  this team, except Hayes, of course.  He was a surprise. They all had flaws  which concealed their real talent,  or I wouldn't have been able to get  them. But I knew if anyone could  straighten them out, you could. And  if you tell them any of this, I will  fire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown can only shake his head at this whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this team, Lou. Go get 'em  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two shake hands. Brown looks at Rachel a beat, still  looking for some sign of duplicity. Finally he gives her grudging smile of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor, Hayes, Vaughn and the others are getting ready to board the bus to the stadium. Taylor pulls Vaughn aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what Dorn's wife is up  to, but I think it'd be best if you  dressed early and got out to the  bullpen before Dorn comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaughn nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Taylor) We got a problem. Cerrano wants some  extra power for tonight. He's lookin'  to sacrifice a live chicken. We can't  have people pukin' in the locker  room before the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him not to worry, I'll take  care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorn is ready to leave for the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye bye, honey, wish me luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you go, there's something I  wanta tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh, we know what this is all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is jammed. 75,000 screaming maniacs, most of th decked out in war paint and head dresses. Some carry plas scalps with Yankee hats on them. Others have caps with th European "No" insignia superimposed over a door mat.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: In the press box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't need it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: THE LOCKER ROOM
